questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of sinusitis?
Identify the most common sinus involved in sinusitis in adults.
questions.explanation: The structure marked 4 is the maxillary sinus and is the most common sinus involved in acutesinusitis in adults.Order of frequency of sinuses involved in acute sinusitis in adults is maxillary > ethmoid >frontal > sphenoid.Paranasal sinusesFrontalsinusEthmoidal- sinusSphenoidal- sinusMaxillary- sinus427

questions.question: A patient with sinusitis is least likely to present with which of the following symptoms?417
questions.explanation: Diplopia is least likely to be seen in sinusitis.Patients with sinusitis typically present with a dull throbbing headache which worsens on movingthe head or bending forward, nasal discharge and blockage, & constitutional symptoms likefever, general malaise and bodyache.Option A: Occipital headache can be seen in sphenoid sinusitis.Option B: Eyelid edema can be seen in frontal and ethmoidal sinusitis.Option D: Post-nasal drip and nasal discharge is a common finding in sinusitis.

questions.question: A 28-year-old IT professional with a recent history of upper respiratory tract infection has aheadache that worsens during office hours. The headache comes upon waking, tends to be atits worst by about midday and improves as the day progresses. This characteristic periodicityis seen in?
questions.explanation: Headache in frontal sinusitis shows characteristic periodicity, i.e. comes upon waking, graduallyincreases, reaches its peak by about midday, and then starts subsiding. It is also called officeheadache because of its presence only during office hours.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common sinusitis in children?
questions.explanation: The ethmoid sinus is the most common sinus involved in pediatric sinusitis.It usually occurs when the infection spreads through the lamina papyracea.

questions.question: A 12-year-old child diagnosed with sphenoid sinusitis was brought to the hospital withcomplaints of a fever and headache. The headache would most likely be localised to?
questions.explanation: Headache in sphenoid sinusitis is localized to occiput or vertex.Frontal headache is seen in maxillary and frontal sinusitis. Headache in frontal sinusitis hascharacteristic periodicity.

questions.question: 418A middle-aged man with a history of recurrent episodes of sinusitis for two years presentedwith complaints of a dull aching pain over his cheek, persistent nasal obstruction whichworsens at night and an urge to constantly clear his throat. Which of the following anteriorrhinoscopy findings is pathognomonic of the condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical history is suggestive of chronic maxillary sinusitis. Mucoid or mucopurulentdischarge in the middle meatus seen on anterior rhinoscopy is a pathognomonic finding inchronic maxillary sinusitis.Other signs include mucosal edema primarily in the middle meatus as well as polyps. Clinically,patients present with nasal blockage, congestion, postnasal drip, reduced olfaction, and facial painor pressure. On CT, mucosal changes within the osteomeatal complex and sinuses may be seen.428

questions.question: A 21-year-old female patient presented with fever, headache, and a hawking sensation. Suspecting severe sinusitis, you order an X-ray of the PNS. Which view would be best in capturing all the paranasal sinuses in a single film?
questions.explanation: The lateral view shows all the paranasal sinuses in a single film. The lateral side of the skull lies against the film, and an X-ray beam is projected perpendicular to the other side. Structures seen are: • Anterior and posterior extent of the sphenoid, frontal sinus • Maxillary sinuses • Ethmoid sinuses • Sella turcica • Alveolar process Condyle and neck of the mandible. Note: Though all the abnormalities and diagnoses of Paranasal sinuses cannot be concluded through the lateral view alone, the lateral view radiographically covers all the sinuses in the same view. Frontal sinus Ethmoid sinus Sphenoid sinus Maxillary sinus Lateral view

questions.question: A patient with deviated nasal septum presents with a headache that starts upon waking andreaches its peak by about midday. On examination, she has upper eyelid oedema andtenderness on pressing just above the medial canthus. Which of the following X-ray views ispreferred to best evaluate the sinus involved?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of frontal sinusitis. The best view for evaluatingthe frontal sinus is Caldwell's view.It is also known as occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position.Structures seen are:• Frontal sinuses• Ethmoid sinuses429• Maxillary sinuses• Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone●Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea•Superior orbital fissure•• Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)Caldwell viewX-ray detectorMX-ray beamIt is also known as occipitofrontal view ornose-forehead position.OMARROW15°

questions.question: Which of the following is used to make a definitive diagnosis of sinusitis?
questions.explanation: Diagnostic nasal endoscopy findings are used to confirm the diagnosis of sinusitis.Indications of diagnostic nasal endoscopy:••To diagnose any disease of the nose and PNSTo find the source of bleeding in epistaxis• To assess response to medical or surgical treatment of the nose and PNS disease•To take a precise biopsy from the nose and nasopharynx

questions.question: Which of the following complications would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed withsinusitis?
questions.explanation: Soft palate paralysis is not a known complication of sinusitis.Complications of paranasal sinus infection:• Local• Mucocele/Mucopyocele• Mucous retention cyst430•Osteomyelitis - Frontal bone (more common), maxilla• Orbital•Preseptal inflammatory oedema of lidsSubperiosteal abscess• Orbital cellulitis• Orbital abscess•Superior orbital fissure syndrome• Orbital apex syndrome• Intracranial• Meningitis• Extradural abscess• Subdural abscess• Brain abscess• Cavernous sinus thrombosis• Descending infections• Focal infections

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common complication following acute rhinosinusitis?
questions.explanation: Orbital cellulitis is the most common complication following acute rhinosinusitis.Complications of acute rhinosinusitis are typically classified as orbital (60-75 per cent),intracranial (15-20 per cent) and osseous (5-10 per cent), and local and descending infections.

questions.question: A 60-year-old lady presents with pain and swelling around the left upper eyelid region, diplopia, and a headache. She gives a history of recurrent episodes of rhinosinusitis in the past. On examination, there is a downward, and outward deviation of the eyeball & the most prominent part of the swelling has a punctum with a mucopurulent discharge, just above the upper eyelid. Which of the following sinuses is most commonly involved in this complication?
questions.explanation: The given clinical history and findings are suggestive of a mucocele secondary to frontal sinusitis. The frontal sinus is most commonly involved in mucocele formation. The sinuses commonly affected by mucocele in the order of frequency are the frontal > ethmoidal > maxillary > sphenoid. The image given below shows a coronal MRI demonstrating a frontal mucocele and an orbital cystic mass.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about mucoceles?

options.A: Frontal sinus is most commonly involved.
options.B: Presents as a cystic swelling in the superomedial quadrant
options.C: Eyeball is pushed downwards, forwards and medially

questions.explanation: Eyeballs are pushed downwards, forwards and laterally. Option A: Frontal sinus is most commonly involved in mucocele. Option B: It presents as a cystic swelling in the superomedial quadrant of the orbit. Option D: Treatment is frontoethmoidectomy with free drainage of the frontal sinus into the middle meatus.

questions.question: A young man was referred to the maxillofacial surgeon with complaints of pain andtenderness over the left cheek, inability to move the left eye, and numbness over the leftforehead. He gave a history of chronic sinusitis for two years. Superior orbital fissuresyndrome was suspected. Which of the following nerves is least likely to be involved in thiscondition?
questions.explanation: The maxillary division of trigeminal nerve does not pass through the superior orbital fissure andthus, is the least likely nerve to be involved in this condition.Superior orbital fissure syndrome is characterized by the compression of cranial nerves III, IV,VI, and ophthalmic division of V. The superior orbital fissure lies between the greater and lesserwings of the sphenoid. The structures passing through include cranial nerves III, IV, VI, theophthalmic branch of V, and the superior ophthalmic vein.432Contents of Superior orbital fissureLacrimal branch of ophthalmic nerve (V)Frontal branch of ophthalmic nerve (V₁)Trochlear nerve (IV)Levator palpebrae superiorisSuperior obliqueInferior ophthalmic vein-Superior ophthalmic veinOMARROWOptic nerveOptic canalOphthalmic arterySuperior branchof oculomotor (III)Nasociliary branchof ophthalmic nerve (V₁).Abducent nerve (VI)Common tendinous ringInferior branch ofoculomotor nerve (III)Orbital apex syndrome is superior orbital fissure syndrome with additional involvement of opticnerve and maxillary division of trigeminal nerve.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true?

options.A: Osteomyelitis of maxilla is more common in children
options.B: Osteomyelitis of frontal bone is more common in adults
options.C: Ethmoidal sinusitis spreads through lamina papyracea
options.D: Pott's puffy tumor is related to osteomyelitis of maxilla

questions.explanation: Pott's puffy tumor refers to osteomyelitis of the frontal bone with the development of asubperiosteal abscess manifesting as a puffy swelling on the forehead or scalp. It usually occurs asa complication of frontal sinusitis.Option A: Osteomyelitis of the maxilla is more often seen in infants and children than adultsbecause of the presence of spongy bone in the anterior wall of the maxilla.Option B: Osteomyelitis of frontal bone is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is notdeveloped in infants and children.Option C: Ethmoidal sinusitis spreads through lamina papyracea

questions.question: A middle-aged patient with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections presentswith diplopia and protrusion of the left eyeball. Inflammation of which of the followingparanasal sinuses would most likely lead to this complication?
questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of orbital complications secondary to sinusitis. The orbitand its contents are closely related to the ethmoid, frontal, and maxillary sinuses, but most of thecomplications, however, follow infection of ethmoids as they are separated from the orbit only bya thin lamina of bone called lamina papyracea.

questions.question: A procedure that involves puncturing and irrigating the sinus is planned for a patient with ahistory of chronic sinusitis. For which of the following paranasal sinuses is this procedureperformed?
questions.explanation: Proof puncture or antral lavage involves puncturing the medial wall of maxillary sinus in theregion of inferior meatus to allow for irrigation and drainage of the sinus.433It is called proof puncture, as the presence of an infection can be proven during the procedure.Antral lavageOMARROWOpening of maxillarysinus in middle meatus-Middle turbinate-Inferior meatusCannula

questions.question: In which of the following conditions is antral lavage not indicated?
questions.explanation: In acute maxillary sinusitis, antral lavage is actually contraindicated due to the risk of osteomyelitis. Antral lavage is usually done therapeutically to remove pus and diagnostically for confirmation of chronic maxillary sinusitis. It can also be done to collect a specimen of the antral contents for culture and sensitivity, or cytological examination to exclude early malignancy.

questions.question: While performing a therapeutic antral lavage of the maxillary sinus, the patient developed afatal complication. He stopped breathing, the colour of his face became ashen grey, and thepupils became dilated. Attempts to resuscitate the patient were futile, and he was declareddead after 20 minutes. Which of the following could be the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: Air embolism is a rare but fatal complication that can occur during antral lavage through the veinsthat are damaged during the puncture.This complication can be prevented by avoiding the insufflation of air into the antrum afterlavage.

questions.question: Which of the following sinuses is accessed via the Caldwell-Luc approach?422
questions.explanation: Caldwell-Luc operation is a surgery where the maxillary antrum is opened through canine fossaby sublabial approach and pathology inside the antrum dealt with.434

questions.question: Which of the following structures is pierced while creating a nasoantral window in CaldwellLuc operation?
questions.explanation: Nasoantral window of <1.5cm in diameter is created through the inferior meatus.Caldwell-Luc surgerySinus opened and diseasedmucous membrane strippedNasoantral window created andoromaxillary opening closedNasoantralwindowOromaxillaryopeningDiseasedmucousmembraneInfraorbitalnorveNasoantralwindowInterior ofmaxillary sinusClinical appearance of opened sinusafter strippingOMARROW

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common complication of Caldwell Luc operation?
questions.explanation: The most common complication of Caldwell Luc operation is infraorbital nerve injury.Paraesthesia due to damage of the infraorbital nerve may be temporary or permanent and isreported in 21% of cases.435Caldwell-Luc surgery38Sinus opened and diseasedmucous membrane strippedNasoantral window created andoromaxillary opening closedNasoantralwindowOromaxillaryopening.DiseasedmucousmembraneInfraorbitalnorveNasoantralwindowwInterior ofmaxillary sinusClinical appearance of opened sinusafter strippingOMARROW

questions.question: What does FESS stand for?
questions.explanation: FESS stands for Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery. FESS is a minimally invasive procedure that uses nasal endoscopes to enlarge the nasal drainage pathways of the paranasal sinuses to improve sinus ventilation and allow access to topical medications.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinussurgery?423
questions.explanation: Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery(FESS).Indications of FESS:⚫ Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment•• Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis• Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball• Nasal polyps• Mucocele• Control of epistaxis••• Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinusBarotrauma sinusitis (pain in the face during descent in aircraft or descent whilst scuba diving)

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.explanation: 436Acute rhinosinusitis with epidural abscess is a contraindication for functional endoscopic sinussurgery.The endoscopic approach is contraindicated in the presence of an intracranial complication ofacute infection such as:•Meningitis• Subperiosteal abscess•⚫ Epidural abscess• Cavernous sinus thrombosis• Any visual lossNote: Endoscopic sinus surgery is indicated in chronic bacterial rhinosinusitis, allergic fungalsinusitis with mycetoma and repair of cerebrospinal fluid leak.

questions.question: Which of the following structures cannot be accessed by performing an endoscopic nasal surgery?
questions.explanation: Cerebellum cannot be accessed by performing endoscopic nasal surgery. Apart from the nose and paranasal sinuses, endoscopic surgery can be used to access the orbit, optic nerve, lacrimal sac, and pituitary gland. Indications of advanced nasal endoscopic techniques: • Removal of benign tumors, e.g., inverted papillomas or angiofibromas • Orbital abscess or cellulitis management. • Dacryocystorhinostomy • Repair of CSF leak • Pituitary surgery • Optic nerve decompression • Orbital decompression for Graves' disease • Control of posterior epistaxis (endoscopic clipping of sphenopalatine artery) • Choanal atresia

questions.question: A 45-year-old-man with a history of chronic sinusitis unresponsive to medications is plannedfor functional endoscopic sinus surgery. Which of the following is the first step in theprocedure?
questions.explanation: Uncinectomy where uncinate process is incised with sickle knife and removed with Blakesleyforceps is the first definitive surgical step in FESS.437Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS)Maxillary sinusOsteomeatal complex-Uncinate process-Middle turbinateInferior turbinateMARROW

questions.question: 424You are a third-year ENT resident performing a functional endoscopic sinus surgery on apatient diagnosed with chronic maxillary sinusitis. During the procedure, the lateral wall ofthe infundibulum is punctured adjacent to the maxillary sinus ostium. Why is this step done?
questions.explanation: Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in FESS and it is done toapproach the middle meatus.

questions.question: Water's view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses?
questions.explanation: Water's view is used to best visualize the maxillary sinus. Frontal and ethmoidal sinuses can alsobe visualized. Sphenoid sinus can be seen in Water's view with open mouth.It is also known as the occipitomental view. The X-ray beam is angled at 37°-45° to theorbitomeatal line.The recommended imaging views for different sinuses are as follows:• Ethmoidal sinus: Rheese's view• Frontal sinus: Caldwell's view•Sphenoid sinus: Hirtz view438Radiographic plat45°Orbitomeatal lineWater's radiographicview of skullOMARROWWater's view / Occipitomental viewEthmoidalsinusNasalseptumDirectionof X-rayFrontalsinusOrbitMaxillarysinusZygomaMandible

questions.question: The radiograph shown below is done for better assessment of the frontal sinus. What is thecommon name of this view?
questions.explanation: The frontal sinus is best seen in Caldwell's view (occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position).The structures seen in Caldwell's view include:• Frontal sinuses (seen best)• Ethmoid sinuses•Maxillary sinuses• Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone•Superior margin of the orbit and lamina papyraceaSuperior orbital fissure439• Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)The nose and forehead are touching the X-ray film and the X-ray beam is projected 15 degreescaudally in Caldwell's view.X-ray detectorX-ray beam0 = 15°Other options:Option A: Water's view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view wherean X-ray beam is angled at 45 degrees to the orbitomeatal line. Structures seen are the maxillarysinus (best seen), sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth), frontal sinus, zygoma,zygomatic arch, nasal bone, and infratemporal fossa.Option C: Pierre's view is the occipitomental with an open mouth. It helps in visualizing thesphenoid sinus as well, in addition to the sinuses that can be seen in water's view.Option D: Towne's view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull. Structures seen arethe petrous part of the pyramids, arcuate eminence, superior semicircular canal, mastoid antrum,internal auditory canal, tympanic cavity, cochlea, and external auditory canal. This view is takenfor acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.440
